Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Dual-Capsule Epoxy Self-Healing Additives for Corrosion Protection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is significant due to the number of critical challenges in the design of protective materials the proposed technology could address. The proposed R&D activity will facilitate the development of a dual-capsule epoxy self-healing system for epoxy protective coatings. The incorporation of such a system into the design of protective and marine epoxy coatings will improve the corrosion resistance of these coatings leading to longer maintenance cycles for these assets along with a decrease in the loss of productivity, energy consumed and volatile organic compounds associated with maintenance, repair and overhaul activities. The product developed will also find utility as a specialty additive for adhesives and sealants spanning multiple consumer and industrial applications. Finally, successful development of this technology will enable the development of novel one-pack epoxy coating and adhesives curable at ambient conditions, curing agents for powder coatings and novel corrosion inhibiting formulations.



This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result in the development of an approach for the microencapsulation of amine curing agents for epoxy resins en route to the development of a dual capsule epoxy-based self-healing system. Due to their amphiphilic properties, curing agents for epoxies, (typically amines and amides) are difficult to encapsulate since they tend to reside at the interface between the oil and the water phases in oil-in-water emulsions that are a prerequisite for most encapsulation procedures. As such, self-healing systems demonstrated even at an academic level have been based other chemistries even in cases in which the matrix is an epoxy. We will approach this problem on two fronts. The first will be the systematic evaluation and selection of an amine curing agent with a degree of hydrophobicity that will permit its encapsulation. Upon successful encapsulation of the amine, the second front will identify an appropriate process for reinforcing the properties of the shell wall to improve its robustness. Following the achievement of adequately stable amine microcapsules, the efficacy of the dual capsule self-healing system combining these capsules with complementary microcapsules containing an epoxy resin, will be assessed in prototype coating and adhesive formulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award Number 1549095 - Autonomic Materials, Inc.

Dual-Capsule Epoxy Self-Healing Additives for Corrosion Protection

 Principal Investigator: Gerald O. Wilson, Ph.D., M.B.A.

Introduction

Since the company started operations in late 2007, Autonomic Materials, Inc. (AMI) has been at the forefront of efforts aimed at realizing the potential of self-healing technology in advanced materials. AMI’s self-healing technologies bring a crucial, but currently missing, element to the design of protective coatings, which is the ability to maintain the coating’s protective capabilities after damage causes exposure of the substrate. The company has developed a range of products, which are currently at various stages of commercial development with some of the world’s largest coating manufacturers. When coating formulations containing AMI’s products are mechanically damaged, the microcapsules that constitute the product are ruptured, releasing their contents into the site of damage. Once in the site of the damage, the contents, which include polymeric material precursors and corrosion inhibitors, cross-link, restoring the coating’s protective capabilities at the site of damage.

The goal of this project was to design dual-capsule epoxy-amine self-healing chemistries targeted at epoxy coating applications. For these applications, epoxy resin-based formulations and amine-based formulations would be compartmentalized within an epoxy coating in separate microcapsules such that damage to the coating would rupture both varieties of microcapsules releasing their contents into the site of damage thereby initiating a cross-linking reaction between the epoxy resin-based and amine-based formulations (Figure 1). While the microencapsulation of epoxy-based formulations for self-healing applications has been previously achieved,1 the encapsulation of amine-based formulations present a more significant challenge due to their amphiphilic nature which renders them more difficult to stabilize in an oil-in-water emulsion, an essential step in microencapsulation.

Results & Discussion

Upon systematic evaluation of a range of amines prior to the start of the project, we identified a class of primary amines that were significantly more hydrophobic than typical epoxy curing agents while maintaining adequate reactivity with epoxy resins. The focus on hydrophobicity stems from the need to facilitate stabilization of the amine and the more hydrophobic the amine, the more facile the stabilization process. A set of 3 hydrophobic amines was evaluated to assess their intrinsic corrosiveness as well as the barrier properties and corrosion resistance of the epoxy-amine polymers they form. A set of 2 out of the 3 was selected for further evaluation in a range of microencapsulation trials.

Multiple encapsulation trials were performed using in-situ encapsulation processes including urea-formaldehyde and melamine-formaldeyde chemistries, interfacial processes employing various combinations of acrylate monomers and solvent evaporation methods using various thermplastics. Although viable microcapsules were made for all the approaches outlined above, the most robust microencapsulation process was achieved via a melamine-formaldehyde microencapsulation process based on a commercially available methylated melamine-formaldehyde reactive prepolymer. Images of two iterations of microcapsules prepared using this process are provided in Figure 2. Although microcapsules obtained from preliminary trials exhibited shell walls that were too thick to rupture as efficiently as would be required during a healing event (Figure 2a), subsequent trials produced capsules with more optimal shell wall thicknesses (Figure 2b).

The ability of the resulting capsules to be ruptured during a healing event and for the hydrophobic amine present within the capsules to be released into the site of damage to cross-link an epoxy resin also present in the site of damage was evaluated in controlled experiments referred to as self-activated control experiments by Brown et al.2 Self-activated experiments test the performance of each component of a self-healing system within the context of optimal delivery of the other components. For a dual capsule epoxy-amine self-healing system, the microcapsules containing the amine were incorporated into an EPON 862/Epikure 3100 matrix molded into Tapered Double Cantilever Beam (TDCB) specimens. The specimens were pin-loaded to failure using a load frame, after which an epoxy resin-based formulation was injected into the resulting fracture planes. The samples were then re-fractured after 48 h or 72 h depending on the test. The results indicated that the hydrophobic amine capsules led to a healing efficiency of ca. 40% (Figure 3a) to 44% (Figure 3c) depending on the healing conditions.

Given the promising nature of the results achieved so far, ongoing work is focused on continued optimization of the encapsulation process to achieve more robust capsules as well as the preparation of capsule sizes commensurate with the dry film thicknesses of target coatings.

References

 1. Caruso, M. M.; Blaiszik, B. J.; White, S. R.; Sottos, N. R; Moore, J. S. Advanced Functional Materials, 2008, 18, 1898 – 1904.

2. Brown, E. N; Sottos, N. R.; White, S. R. Experimental Mechanics, 2002, 42, 372 – 379.

Modified by: Gerald Wilson

  • Figure 2. Optical micrographs of capsules containing hydrophobic amine. The capsules were prepared using a methylated melamine-formaldehyde reactive prepolymer. (a) Capsules in slurry form from preliminary trials, (b) Capsules with decreased shell wall thickness dispersed in hexyl acetate.
    Autonomic Materials, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Wilson
    Figure 2.
  • Figure 3. Comparison of representative load-displacement curves of virgin fracture (blue) and self-activated healed fracture (red) achieved by injecting an epoxy resin-based formulation into the fracture plane after the virgin fracture. TDCB samples healed for (a) 48 h at RT, (b) 72 h at 50 °C.
    Autonomic Materials, Inc.
